statement.tex: \text{Find the matrix X so that }\\ X\cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \end{array} \right]= \left[\begin{array}{ccc} -7 & -8 & -9 \\ 2 & 4 & 6 \end{array} \right]

step.tex: n = p \text{ and matrix C has order }m\times q
step.reason: \text{If matrix $A_{m\times n}$ and $B_{p\times q}$ can be multiplied,}\\ \text{then $n = p$ and the resulting product matrix}\\ \text{is of order }m\times q

step.context: \text{Does solving following equations yield unique}\\ \text{values for a and b?}\\ a+4b=-7, 2a+5b=-8, 3a+6b=-9
step.tex: \text{Solving for a and b, using any two of the}\\ \text{above equations gives $a=1$ and $b=-2$.}
\text{A unique result is not possible as we have more}\\ \text{equations (3) than variables (2).}

step.context: \text{Does solving following equations yield unique}\\ \text{values for c and d?}\\ c+4d=2, 2c+5d=4, 3c+6d=6
step.tex: \text{Solving for a and b, using any two of the}\\ \text{above equations gives $c=2$ and $d=0$.}
\text{A unique result is not possible as we have more}\\ \text{equations (3) than variables (2).}
